title: The allegations of racism against Trump did not begin when the Democrats were challenged.
text: The political loyalty of President Donald Trump has been compromised between the parties, and the Facebook article recently indicates that the Democrats have only accused him of racism since he left their camp. "Donald Trump has been in public for over 30 years," said the article on May 16, and he was never accused of being racist by anyone until he decided to run against Democrats. This article, which presents images of Trump with black characters such as the Civil Rights Activist, Sharpton and the winner of the trainee Randall Pinkett, was highlighted as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation on the news. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) But the truth is that Trump has resisted the accusations of racism almost as long as the public sees it - long before his involvement in politics. An opinion article published in January 2018 in The New York Times describes Trump as racist. "He talks about people and treats them differently based on their race" tells the story. "He's done it for years, and he's still doing it." This article compiles quotations from Trump before running for the presidency as a Republican representative in the 2016 elections and cites events such as when Tramp Real Estate attempted in the 1970s to avoid renting apartments to Afro-Americans. An article in February documents the so-called "Long History of Racism" from the 1970s to the present. The story refers to the first time Trump appeared in The New York Times - 16 October 1973 - when the newspaper published a story on the first page about a lawsuit against a child then 27 years old and his father. "The main owner was accused of prejudice against blacks in the city," said the headline. The story begins: "The Ministry of Justice accuses blacks of discrimination in the rental of apartments, and yesterday she sued the Brooklyn Federal Court against the Trump Management Company, a major owner and real estate manager here. The company, which owns and rents more than 14,000 apartments in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, was accused of violating the Fair Housing Act 1968 in the operation of 39 buildings." The Ministry of Justice claimed that "the Trump Administration refused to rent or negotiate rents due to race and colour," as reported by The Times. She also accused the company that the company required different rent terms because of race and that she had offended the blacks that the apartments were not available. Under an agreement reached in June 1975, the company was required to provide the New York Urban Association with a list of all vacant apartments every week for two years. The Trump administration said that the agreement was not a guilty plea. Almost two decades later, in 1989, Trump published an announcement in New York City newspapers calling for the imposition of the death penalty on black suspects in the so-called "Fugitive from Central Park" case, accusing five juveniles of rape and beating a young white woman.
